repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Tocantins Sustainable Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tocantins Sustainable
            Regional Development Project for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            political cycles had a clear impact on the rhythm of
            implementation of the Project. This challenge is amplified
            in multi-sector operations given the larger number of
            entities involved in implementation. To address this
            challenge, Projects should try to limit the number of
            entities, recognize the risk or factor in political
            variables in Project design. Moreover, the distribution of
            Bank and counterpart financing should take into account
            incentives or disincentives at political levels, as was the
            case under this operation, to ensure that activities with
            lower political visibility are still undertaken in a timely
            fashion. Although multiple institutions and stakeholders are
            involved in multi-sector operations, projects should design
            some degree of centralization under a unified Project
            Implementation Unit to make complex operations more
            manageable and expedite implementation, particularly to
            facilitate multiple procurement processes. From the
            Bank's perspective, these multi-sector operations that
            involve numerous activities and procurement processes
            inevitably rely on strengthened and intensified Bank
            supervision. A long term lesson learned through past Bank
            experiences in the State is the need to move beyond narrow
            approaches to improving accessibility (focusing on trunk
            infrastructure or isolated interventions on municipal
            roads), and adopting a more integrated approach both
            vertically, within the road network to link various road
            levels to provide seamless logistics, and horizontally among
            various other regional development requirements. This
            'holistic' approach, which is inherently more
            complex to implement, and to which the new proposed
            operation is ultimately responding, relies on strong
            coordination between the different Government levels,
            ensuring that micro interventions at local level are
            supplemented by investments undertaken at regional and
            national level.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Tocantins Sustainable Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Tocantins
            Sustainable Regional Development Project is to contribute to
            raising living standards and to reducing inequalities and
            regional disparities in Brazil by improving access to
            markets, job opportunities, infrastructure and social
            services for rural communities in Tocantins' poorest
            regions, while ensuring sustainable use of natural resources
            and the protection of fragile ecosystems. The project is
            comprised of three components.  The participatory planning
            and management of regional and municipal development
            component will establish or strengthen mechanisms for local
            civil society participation; set up regional units of
            SEPLAN; and strengthen capacity to undertake multisectoral
            state-level planning, to administer public programs, and
            monitor/evaluate the performance of such programs. The
            environmental management component will: strengthen land
            management capacity; consolidate the environmental
            protection system; and support the regulation and promotion
            of sustainable land use.  The rural transport improvement
            component will: (a) strengthen road management capacity, by
            ensuring the preparation, monitoring and evaluation of
            efficient state road programs, and gradually increasing the
            road maintenance capacity; (b) define and improve about
            6,000 km of priority road sections of the main municipal
            road networks and improve about 120 km of high-priority
            state feeder roads including reconstruction of bridges and
            culverts, rehabilitation of road surfaces and bases, and
            paving; (c) promote cost-effective rural transport services,
            particularly school bus systems, and establish mechanisms to
            improve access of the rural poor to such services; and (d)
            provide support to the project coordination unit.

repnme.cdata!:
Brasil - Projeto de Infra-estrutura Rural a
            Tocantins : diretrizes basicas para o desenvolvimento dos
            povos indigenas no ambito das obras rodoviarias

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tocantins Rural Infrastructure
            Project seeks to improve traffic conditions, and
            transportation costs, to in turn further consolidate the
            policy on appropriate uses of the State's natural
            resources. In light of the project's impending road
            construction, this Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) reviews the
            Constitution's articles relevant to indigenous peoples
            rights, as well as the Regulation of the Indigenous National
            Foundation (FUNAI) (Annexes I and II), to establish
            procedures for project implementation, avoiding as possible,
            or minimizing, adverse impacts on the lives of indigenous
            populations. It is noted that legislation stipulates a
            radius of ten kilometers should protect indigenous reserves,
            and, activities potentially endangering biodiversity, should
            abide by the norms set by the National Council for the
            Environment (CONAMA). However, taking into consideration the
            above mentioned laws and regulations, an environmental
            assessment on various alternatives, comparative analyses for
            the design of road networks, and local consultations, the
            alternative proposed states that, the new road segment
            traversing indigenous land, would provide the opportunity
            for land restoration of vast areas previously subjected to
            agricultural, and livestock practices, and, its proximity to
            the city of Nazare - currently isolated - would provide
            positive social, and economic benefits to the region.
